node.text: Chamath Palihapitiya is a Silicon Valley staple. The tech billionaire has a devoted online following and is behind some of the biggest IPOs of the past year, thanks to something called a SPAC. And while he didn’t invent SPACs, he's used them to forever change how companies go public. (via @businessweek)

node.title: The Tech Billionaire Who Became the King of SPACs

node.text: "Wayfinding" systems are the smart design tools that help people navigate from place to place. It's a universal language that exists everywhere — from the roads we drive, the paths we walk, and the airports and malls we traverse. There's also a natural version in our brains. Without it, we'd be getting lost a whole lot more.

node.title: The Subtle Design Keeping Us From Getting Lost

node.text:
The 9/11 terror attack on New York killed 2,753 people and in the two decades since, the scale of the losses for the city and Wall Street still stagger. Three out of every four people who worked in New York for the brokerage Cantor Fitzgerald, 658 in all, died when the North Tower collapsed. 

At the boutique bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, 67 of the 171 New York employees were killed when the South Tower fell. At Aon, 176 were killed.

The list goes on. 

On this 20th anniversary, Wall Street looks back.

node.text:
Take Pokemon-like gameplay, throw in NFTs and you have Axie Infinity.

The game lets players like 22-year-old John Aaron Ramos accumulate tradeable crypto coins and earn real money — in his case, enough to buy two apartments. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Axie Infinity: How a Game is Turning Players Into Crypto Traders

node.text: NFTs burst on the scene with a $69 million sale of Beeple's digital art. Now players behind the so-called metaverse are betting "digital scarcity" will create a whole new ecosystem of play and commerce.

node.title: How NFTs Are Reinventing the Digital World

node.text:
"I would describe cryptocurrencies as a limited supply of nothing."

John Paulson—who's famous bet against subprime housing made him and investors $20 billion—says crypto is a "worthless" bubble and he calls SPACs, one of the hottest investing tools, a losing proposition.

Paulson told @bloombergtv in an interview on "Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein" he's more concerned about rising prices. The rapidly expanding money supply could push inflation rates well above current expectations, he said, and gold, which he’s backed for years, is primed for its moment.

Paulson’s dismissal of crypto is sure to attract critics after digital assets vastly outperformed gold in recent years. Watch the full episode Tuesday at 9pm ET on BloombergTV and read the Big Take in our stories.

node.title: Cryptocurrencies are a Bubble, Says Billionaire Paulson

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text: An anonymous donor turned a tiny Pacific coast town without a bank into the world's biggest Bitcoin experiment. Here's how life has changed on El Savaldor's Bitcoin beach. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Bitcoin Beach: The Surf Town That Went Crypto

node.text: In West Texas, vast quantities of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, are leaking into the atmosphere. Specialized cameras that can detect the invisible pollutant are helping to expose the problem.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Can your boss force you back to the office? Bloomberg'.

node.text:
As employers grapple with how to get people back into the office, lawyers have one key message for them: tread carefully, because lawsuits are coming.

It won't be as straightforward as employers simply telling workers to get back in. Bosses expect resistance, and issues around employment contracts, health and safety policies and vaccines are all flashpoints that could lead to litigation.

We asked three employment lawyers in the U.K., where the return to office is gathering pace, what the rules mean for staff and managers. Tap the link in our bio for our Q&A.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, lake and text that says 'Even the rich think it will take a "miracle' to retire Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
It takes a lot of money to retire and live well — and even wealthy Americans are worried.

A survey of investors with portfolios worth a median $450,000 found two in five think it will take "a miracle" for them to stop working and still enjoy decades of financial security. The younger the age group, the more concerned they were.

Where you live is an important part of the equation. Iceland remains the best country for retirees, according to the Natixis Global Retirement Index. The U.S., meanwhile, slipped to 17th position in their latest annual ranking. See more at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says '"Inflation guy" has been preparing for this moment for almost20 years Bloomberg'.

node.text:
After decades of modest growth in consumer prices, investors had stopped worrying about inflation much — until now. Suddenly, Michael Ashton finds himself really busy.

In the early 2000s, he was a derivatives trader at Barclays Capital in New York when he was tapped to build a business around inflation swaps, contracts that let traders bet on a rise in consumer prices. He says the real job was to build a new market by being “an evangelist for the product.”

Ashton became one even though, until recently, he (correctly) expected inflation to be low and stable. In 2009 he founded an advisory business for hedging large or unusual inflation risks, and remained a voice in the desert crying out that he had rain boots for sale. “The lack of interest was amazing,” he says. “It’s incredible how little people thought about it — what that risk was.”

Suddenly, that’s no longer true. Inflation has spiked this year, and while Fed chair Jerome Powell says it’s probably a temporary supply shock as the economy emerges from lockdown, Ashton sees more on the way. Read more at the link in bio. (via @businessweek)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Osaka. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Japan's richest person built a $38 billion fortune ithout ever going to college Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
There's a reason that billionaire Takemitsu Takizaki is Japan's new richest person: His company’s share price has doubled since the start of last year.

Takizaki is a factory-automation entrepreneur. Demand for the electronic sensors made by his secretive Osaka-based company, Keyence, has surged in the pandemic, giving it a market value of about $167 billion. His personal fortune now stands at $38.2 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

Tap the link in our bio for more on how an inventor who didn't go to college became one of the richest men in the world.

📷: Keyence Corp. headquarters in Osaka, Japan

node.text: Chamath Palihapitiya is a Silicon Valley staple. The tech billionaire has a devoted online following and is behind some of the biggest IPOs of the past year, thanks to something called a SPAC. And while he didn’t invent SPACs, he's used them to forever change how companies go public. (via @businessweek)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Business on September 18, 2021 tagging @bloombergopinion. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'How to cope with burnout when everyone around you is quitting BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
As the great resignation takes hold, workers across industries are sharing similar stories of burnout, writes @bloombergopinion's Teresa Ghilarducci.

Most employees are working more hours each week compared to pre-pandemic times, especially in health-care and other service-oriented jobs. So what can those employees who don't have the luxury of quitting or feel obligated to stay do when they feel crushed?

The most logical place to start is by talking to an employer, many of whom are probably loathe to lose any more people.

Tap the link in our bio to read more of our tips for overworked individuals.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Cheval Blanc Paris. May be an image of text that says 'Inside LVMH's new luxury hotelin Paris, where rooms cost$1 500 night Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The luxury goods behemoth LVMH has spent 16 years and $900 million creating the Cheval Blanc Paris. Here's the result.

Housed in a 1928 art deco building near the Louvre, the hotel offers incredible views of the Seine from countless terraces and bay windows. A showstopping 100-foot infinity pool in the basement is one of the largest of any hotel in France. The top-floor apartment, among the biggest penthouses in Paris at 11,000 square feet, has its own 41-foot pool and panoramic terrace.

From $1,500 a night, guests can sample rooms adorned with contemporary art and a host of products from the company's luxury brands. Or you can take a look around at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 18, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing, indoor and text that says 'London's 13 best new restaurants, according to topchefs top chefs Bloomberg'.

node.text:
During the Covid-19 pandemic, Londoners lost such standards as the Greenhouse in Mayfair and the Ledbury. But local foodies say the places filling the void are the most exciting they've seen in years.

We asked top chefs to pick their favorite new spots. Their 13 recommendations include a captivating French dining room and a café from a Syrian refugee. Tap the link in our bio to see more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 18, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing, indoor and text that says '0 Singapore's rising rents have lonely expats turning toco -living Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
Forget swanky private apartments. In Singapore, some expats are happy with a room.

Co-living — where you rent a room and share communal spaces like kitchens — is gaining in popularity with overseas professionals as rents rise and the pandemic takes some shine off a gilded lifestyle.

It’s not quite student accommodation — think heritage buildings, cleaning services and on-site gyms. Even so, it illustrates how things have changed for some expats in the city-state. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 6 people and text that says 'Alwan n These are the world's richest families Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The last 12 months have been kind to the world’s richest families.
 
Abundant liquidity, soaring stock markets and accommodating tax policies mean the 25 wealthiest families are now worth $1.7 trillion — a 22% increase on a year ago.

The Waltons of Arkansas, who own nearly half of Walmart, top the list for a fourth year running — but there is movement elsewhere. The New York-based Lauders, of cosmetics fame, have joined the ranking; meanwhile the Lees, owners of South Korea’s Samsung, are among notable names to drop off. Tap the link in bio to see in full.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Meet the finfluencers earning more than Wall Streetbankers Street Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
Until last year, Austin Hankwitz was toiling away in old-fashioned finance, working on mergers and acquisitions for a health care company. Not anymore.
 
The 25-year-old started making TikTok videos as a side hustle. When financial firms noticed his posts caused a spike in their signups, the sponsorships started rolling in. This year, after quitting his job to make content full-time, he expects to bring in more than $500,000 from paid posts, brand partnerships and his Patreon channel.
